shared_diagnostic_path.reasoning_pattern: Blistering → biopsy + immunofluorescence → classify autoimmune type

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and manage a patient presenting with itchy blisters in the axilla.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient, who recently moved to an assisted living facility, complains of itchy blisters that have developed in his axilla. He believes these blisters are due to a poor diet. Additionally, he mentions that since arriving at the facility, a nurse practitioner has started him on four new medications, adding to his already existing prescription regimen.

Secondary_Symptoms: Belief that condition is due to poor diet

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Details on specific past medical history are not provided, but patient has been on multiple medications prior to the new additions at the facility.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: No details provided. Focus on patient's current living situation in an assisted living facility and recent medication changes.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Focused on skin symptoms; negative for fever, recent illnesses, or other systemic symptoms.

Dermatological_Examination.Inspection: Tense axillary bullae noted on the affected area.
Dermatological_Examination.Palpation: The bullae do not rupture with light, gloved touch. Surrounding skin is warm and appears inflamed.

Direct_Immunofluorescence.Findings: Linear C3 and IgG deposits along the basement membrane.

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose the patient presenting with blisters on her forearm and ulcers on mucosal surfaces.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports the appearance of blisters on her forearm 3 days ago, accompanied by pain in her left cheek when eating and pain during sexual intercourse for the past week. She has been hiking in the woods recently but denies contact with poison ivy. She has a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis, recently started taking captopril, and discontinued meloxicam 2 weeks ago. Family history includes pernicious anemia and Graves' disease.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Multiple, flaccid blisters on the volar surface of the forearm
Secondary_Symptoms: Ulcers on the buccal, gingival, and vulvar mucosa
Pain in the left cheek when eating

Patient_Actor.Drug_History: Recently started captopril, stopped taking meloxicam 2 weeks ago.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Has started hiking in the woods on weekends. No relevant travel history.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: No recent illnesses, denies fever, respiratory symptoms, or gastrointestinal symptoms.

Skin_Examination.Inspection: Multiple, flaccid blisters on the volar surface of the forearm, with 10% total body surface area involvement.
Skin_Examination.Palpation: Skin separation (Nikolsky sign positive) when lightly stroked.
Skin_Examination.Mucosal_Examination: Ulcers present on the buccal, gingival, and vulvar mucosa.

Direct_Immunofluorescence.Findings: Intercellular IgG and C3 deposition within the epidermis.
